articles.headline: Rice Visits Iraq With Rumsfeld to Press Leader
articles.snippet: They pressed the prime minister-designate to re-establish public confidence in the government and rid Iraq's forces of infiltration by militias.
articles.abstract: They pressed the prime minister-designate to re-establish public confidence in the government and rid Iraq's forces of infiltration by militias.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 26 â€” Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld paid an unannounced visit to Iraq on Wednesday to press the prime minister-designate to re-establish public confidence in the government and rid the country's security forces of infiltration by sectarian militias.
articles.byline: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN  and DAVID S. CLOUD

articles.headline: 4 Knight Ridder Papers to Be Sold for $1 Billion
articles.snippet: The MediaNews newspaper chain controlled by William Dean Singleton announced plans on Wednesday to acquire four Knight Ridder newspapers, although two papers would first pass through the hands of another chain, the Hearst Corporation.     The four...
articles.abstract: The MediaNews newspaper chain controlled by William Dean Singleton announced plans on Wednesday to acquire four Knight Ridder newspapers, although two papers would first pass through the hands of another chain, the Hearst Corporation.     The four papers, fetching a price of $1 billion in cash, are among 12 Knight Ridder publications that the McClatchy Company agreed to buy last month but does not want.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE, April 26 - The MediaNews newspaper chain controlled by William Dean Singleton announced plans on Wednesday to acquire four Knight Ridder newspapers, although two papers would first pass through the hands of another chain, the Hearst Corporation.

articles.headline: GRAND JURY GETS ROVE TESTIMONY OVER C.I.A. LEAK
articles.snippet: Karl Rove, the senior counselor to President Bush, testified for several hours on Wednesday before the federal grand jury in the C.I.A. leak case, in an appearance that was a sign of renewed attention by the special prosecutor in a matter that has...
articles.abstract: Karl Rove, the senior counselor to President Bush, testified for several hours on Wednesday before the federal grand jury in the C.I.A. leak case, in an appearance that was a sign of renewed attention by the special prosecutor in a matter that has lingered unresolved for months.     It was the fifth time Mr. Rove has appeared before a federal grand jury in the case. The appearance came at a politically sensitive time for Mr. Rove, who was relieved of his policy portfolio at the White House in a staff reshuffling earlier this month and now faces the challenge of helping Republicans maintain their primacy in the midterm elections this fall.

articles.headline: New Tricks of a Browser Look Familiar
articles.snippet: ABOUT 85 percent of the Internet population uses the Microsoft Internet Explorer browser to surf the Web, even though it's relatively ancient, crusty with neglect and about as secure as a screen door. In what other industry would 85 percent of con...
articles.abstract: ABOUT 85 percent of the Internet population uses the Microsoft Internet Explorer browser to surf the Web, even though it's relatively ancient, crusty with neglect and about as secure as a screen door. In what other industry would 85 percent of consumers choose such a product -- when better ones, also free, were also available?     Trick question. Those consumers aren't actually choosing Internet Explorer; in fact, they're not choosing. They just use what came on their Windows computers. Thanks to this built-in following, Microsoft hasn't felt much need to keep Internet Explorer current. Version 6 has been creaking along for five years -- an eternity in Internet time.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABOUT 85 percent of the Internet population uses the Microsoft Internet Explorer browser to surf the Web, even though it's relatively ancient, crusty with neglect and about as secure as a screen door. In what other industry would 85 percent of consumers choose such a product -- when better ones, also free, were also available?

articles.headline: Evacuees Find Housing Grants Will End Soon
articles.snippet: Thousands of hurricane evacuees who counted on a year of free housing and utilities are being told by the Federal Emergency Management Agency that they are no longer eligible for such help and must either pay the rent themselves or leave.      Of ...
articles.abstract: Thousands of hurricane evacuees who counted on a year of free housing and utilities are being told by the Federal Emergency Management Agency that they are no longer eligible for such help and must either pay the rent themselves or leave.      Of about 55,000 families who were given long-term housing vouchers, nearly a third are receiving notices that they no longer qualify, FEMA officials said. For the rest, benefits are also being cut: they will have to sign new leases, pay their own gas and electric bills and requalify for rental assistance every three months.

articles.headline: Lay Loses His Cool on Stand
articles.snippet: After waiting 13 weeks to respond to his accusers, Kenneth L. Lay lost his legendary cool on the witness stand Wednesday.     Just minutes into his cross-examination by a prosecutor, John Hueston, Mr. Lay, Enron's founder and former chief executiv...
articles.abstract: After waiting 13 weeks to respond to his accusers, Kenneth L. Lay lost his legendary cool on the witness stand Wednesday.     Just minutes into his cross-examination by a prosecutor, John Hueston, Mr. Lay, Enron's founder and former chief executive, testily accused Mr. Hueston of personally preventing him from repaying a company credit line Mr. Lay had used to shore up his personal finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, April 26 - After waiting 13 weeks to respond to his accusers, Kenneth L. Lay lost his legendary cool on the witness stand Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Alexei Barrionuevo and Simon Romero

articles.headline: The Shareholder Spring
articles.snippet: Annual shareholder meetings are typically dull, scripted affairs, but as executives and directors of public companies step into the spotlight at this year's gatherings, some for the first time are hearing organized and articulate shareholder disco...
articles.abstract: Annual shareholder meetings are typically dull, scripted affairs, but as executives and directors of public companies step into the spotlight at this year's gatherings, some for the first time are hearing organized and articulate shareholder discontent.     And officials at many of those companies are digging in their heels, using stockholder-financed war chests to resist shareholder demands for more say in executive pay practices and director elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: Annual shareholder meetings are typically dull, scripted affairs, but as executives and directors of public companies step into the spotlight at this year's gatherings, some for the first time are hearing organized and articulate shareholder discontent.

articles.headline: Second Thoughts in Congress on Oil Tax Breaks
articles.snippet: As anxiety spread in Congress on Wednesday over soaring oil prices, lawmakers in both parties said they were ready to take a tough look at oil and gas incentives they passed as recently as eight months ago.     Citing record industry profits and h...
articles.abstract: As anxiety spread in Congress on Wednesday over soaring oil prices, lawmakers in both parties said they were ready to take a tough look at oil and gas incentives they passed as recently as eight months ago.     Citing record industry profits and huge executive pay packages, the top Republican and top Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee asked the Internal Revenue Service to turn over tax returns for the nation's 15 biggest oil and gas companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26 - As anxiety spread in Congress on Wednesday over soaring oil prices, lawmakers in both parties said they were ready to take a tough look at oil and gas incentives they passed as recently as eight months ago.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Michael Janofsky

articles.headline: Rice Visits Iraq With Rumsfeld to Press Leader
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld paid an unannounced visit to Iraq on Wednesday to press the prime minister-designate to re-establish public confidence in the government and rid the country's security...
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld paid an unannounced visit to Iraq on Wednesday to press the prime minister-designate to re-establish public confidence in the government and rid the country's security forces of infiltration by sectarian militias.     Both cabinet secretaries also sought to put the past differences between the departments behind them by emphasizing that they would be working more cooperatively to bolster the Iraqi government, which the prime minister-designate, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, says he wants to finish putting together in the next several days.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 26 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld paid an unannounced visit to Iraq on Wednesday to press the prime minister-designate to re-establish public confidence in the government and rid the country's security forces of infiltration by sectarian militias.
articles.byline: By Steven R. Weisman and David S. Cloud

articles.headline: Doctors Urge Safety Panels for Devices
articles.snippet: A major medical group called yesterday for sweeping changes in how the medical device industry and the government oversee implanted heart devices, and urged companies to use outside experts to help them decide when to issue alerts about potential ...
articles.abstract: A major medical group called yesterday for sweeping changes in how the medical device industry and the government oversee implanted heart devices, and urged companies to use outside experts to help them decide when to issue alerts about potential safety problems in products.      The group, the Heart Rhythm Society, which represents specialists who implant devices like defibrillators, said it believed that ''single adverse events that could cause death or serious injuries in patients merit notification'' if the problem was likely to recur.
articles.lead_paragraph: A major medical group called yesterday for sweeping changes in how the medical device industry and the government oversee implanted heart devices, and urged companies to use outside experts to help them decide when to issue alerts about potential safety problems in products.
